Our responsibility in the ecological transition is to leave nobody behind.
If you talk to people about the end of the world they will be less receptive if their first concern is how to get to the end of the month.
Social sustainability must come with environmental sustainability.

I can’t be a female candidate. 

But I can offer you a candidate who is a feminist. 

#PESinLisbon
@PES_Women
Our society cannot afford to put half of humanity and half of its talent on the back burner. We need equality for men and women. At home and in the workplace.

Tax competition is a thing of the past. It could work when countries were strong and companies were weak. It can’t work now that the companies are so big they can twist the arm of individual countries.

A 16 year old kid on a bike with a backpack who is delivering your dinner is not an entrepreneur. 

We need to find the few extra cents it takes to protect these kids when they fall off the bike or get sick and can’t work.

#PESInLisbon
As far as I am concerned, the United Kingdom will always be welcome as a member of the European family.
Looking at the United Kingdom and having listened to Jeremy Corbyn and his plans yesterday, I have a question: Can you achieve what you want more easily as a member do the EU family or on your own?
The Brexit vote was the lowest point in my political life. We respect the vote. But since that vote much has changed in the world. And the EU has changed. #PESinLisbon

There are 3 visions for Europe:
- The autocrats and nationalists want to destroy Europe
- The conservatives want to freeze Europe where it is now
- The Progressives want to adapt and move forward
These are not ordinary elections. These elections are about the soul of Europe. #PESinLisbon
The past is our teacher, but it should not be our future #PESInLisbon
For socialists and social democrats it is never enough to be happy where we are. We need to strive for a better world for ourselves, our children and our grandchildren. #PESinLisbon

While we may worship in different ways, our values are universal, including our commitment to democracy and equality.

Every European citizen will have a chance to shape our common future at the ballot box next year, and I invited the participants in today's meeting to engage actively in the political process and to encourage their communities to do so as well.

Ahead of next year's European elections, I reassured the participants in today's meeting that the European Commission will continue to stand up and speak up against any discrimination or attacks that their communities might face.

It is our sincere hope that Poland will now urgently address the key concerns identified by the Commission, in particular by taking urgent action before 3 July in relation to the situation of the Supreme Court judges.

That is why the Commission has asked the Council to organise a formal hearing of Poland under the Article 7(1) procedure. Finding a solution is a matter of common interest for all Member States and EU Institutions.
The Commission must sadly conclude that the laws adopted in April and May are not by themselves sufficient to eliminate the clear risk of a serious breach of the rule of law in Poland.

Constitutional Tribunal judgements from 2016 still remain to be published without additional qualifications as to their legality, and no steps have been taken to restore the independence of the Constitutional Tribunal.
Recent changes do not eliminate the broad criteria governing the extraordinary appeal procedure, and maintain the 20-year historical reach of this procedure.

The revised laws offer no solution to court presidents already dismissed by the Minister of Justice or to Ordinary Court judges already forced to retire, including female judges forced out in breach of EU anti-discrimination law.
The politicisation of the National Council for the Judiciary still undermines its role as an effective safeguard of judicial independence.

On 3 July, 27 out of 72 Supreme Court judges face the risk of being forced to retire, and the First President of the Supreme Court would have her mandate prematurely terminated two years early, even though it is guaranteed by the Polish Constitution.
The discretionary powers over the mandates of Supreme Court and Ordinary Court judges are still a key concern in terms of the separation of powers and independence of the judiciary.
However, overall, despite these changes, key concerns which the Commission identified in its Reasoned Proposal remain unaddressed.

4 laws were adopted in April & May. I welcome the change which provides now for the same retirement age for male and female judges, and the willingness of the Polish authorities to discuss the other issues.
Today I updated the European Parliament on the situation with the rule of law in Poland. A number of measures have been taken by the Polish authorities since we last met.

To create change we need to show what the positive agenda is: better work-life balance, letting men have more time to be good fathers, sharing responsibility, letting women develop their careers, making sure that on boards and in the workforce we are more balanced.

There is still a pay gap, a pension gap, an opportunity gap, and even a leisure gap. Women simply have less time to go to the theatre, or the gym, or have drinks with friends. Because the pressure on women to take on multiple tasks is still enormous.
The fight of our grandparents and our parents is a fight worth continuing, because I don't want my daughters to end up in the same situation my mother was, or even my grandmother was.

Gender equality is good for business. It is something we need to do. We  cannot afford to put half of the brainpower of humankind on the  backburner. It is clear that companies which strike a balance, also a gender balance or a diversity balance, outperform other companies.
Yesterday I spoke at the launch of the Bloomberg Gender Equality Index. Creating transparency around gender equality in the workplace is essential. That’s why this instrument is so important.

That is why the Commission has asked the Council to organise a formal hearing of Poland under the Article 7(1) procedure. Finding a solution is a matter of common interest for all Member States and EU Institutions.
The Commission must sadly conclude that the laws adopted in April and May are not by themselves sufficient to eliminate the clear risk of a serious breach of the rule of law in Poland.

Constitutional Tribunal judgements from 2016 still remain to be published without additional qualifications as to their legality, and no steps have been taken to restore the independence of the Constitutional Tribunal.
Recent changes do not eliminate the broad criteria governing the extraordinary appeal procedure, and maintain the 20-year historical reach of this procedure.

The revised laws offer no solution to court presidents already dismissed by the Minister of Justice or to Ordinary Court judges already forced to retire, including female judges forced out in breach of EU anti-discrimination law.
The politicisation of the National Council for the Judiciary still undermines its role as an effective safeguard of judicial independence.

On 3 July, 27 out of 72 Supreme Court judges face the risk of being forced to retire, and the First President of the Supreme Court would have her mandate prematurely terminated two years early, even though it is guaranteed by the Polish Constitution.
The discretionary powers over the mandates of Supreme Court and Ordinary Court judges are still a key concern in terms of the separation of powers and independence of the judiciary.
However, overall, despite these changes, key concerns which the Commission identified in its Reasoned Proposal remain unaddressed.

4 laws were adopted in April & May. I welcome the change which provides now for the same retirement age for male and female judges, and the willingness of the Polish authorities to discuss the other issues.
Today I updated the European Parliament on the situation with the rule of law in Poland. A number of measures have been taken by the Polish authorities since we last met.

To create change we need to show what the positive agenda is: better work-life balance, letting men have more time to be good fathers, sharing responsibility, letting women develop their careers, making sure that on boards and in the workforce we are more balanced.

There is still a pay gap, a pension gap, an opportunity gap, and even a leisure gap. Women simply have less time to go to the theatre, or the gym, or have drinks with friends. Because the pressure on women to take on multiple tasks is still enormous.
The fight of our grandparents and our parents is a fight worth continuing, because I don't want my daughters to end up in the same situation my mother was, or even my grandmother was.

Gender equality is good for business. It is something we need to do. We  cannot afford to put half of the brainpower of humankind on the  backburner. It is clear that companies which strike a balance, also a gender balance or a diversity balance, outperform other companies.
Yesterday I spoke at the launch of the Bloomberg Gender Equality Index. Creating transparency around gender equality in the workplace is essential. That’s why this instrument is so important.

We will launch a public consultation in the coming weeks. This process could culminate in a proposal to revise the ECI Regulation this year.
There are obstacles to a more accessible and citizen-friendly ECI which have their origin in provisions of the ECI Regulation itself.
Where people used to say "Europe doesn't listen", I want them to say "Let's make Europe listen. Let's start a European Citizens' Initiative"
Respecting the legal criteria is inescapable, but we have shown that we can evolve, and partially register Initiatives.
We're only at the beginning of the ECI. We have worked within the current Regulation to make concrete improvements.
We're creating a European public sphere more than we realise.People in Europe watch each other's elections.Our fates are linked. #ECIDay2017

With a project, however small, for Roma children at an early age you can bring change to individuals and to whole communities.
We need a comprehensive approach which comes from Roma communities themselves. We have made huge progress in 20 years, doing this together.
You don't learn mutual respect through books, you learn it by being at school with other children.Equal access to education is a first step.
Around 50% of Roma children don't have access to education. 1/3 go to bed hungry at least once a month. We have to fix it.
If you make a list of the top scapegoats in European history, you will find Roma right up there.
Knowledge and communication are our best tools to fight hatred and fear and to promote open and inclusive societies.
A quote from Dr Martin Luther King to start my speech on Roma education. A lesson I thought we had learned, but fear we have not. https://t.co/ypmrQI43Ej

A new crisis has come along: the crisis of evidence and facts. Our answer must be to defend evidence-based policy making.
We are open to other ideas about how to improve our better regulation tools together with interested parties
But we must still improve the use of our feedback tools – and make the most of the new consultation opportunities
I see public feedback influencing decisions on endocrine disruptors and roaming rates which used to be seen as technocratic and undemocratic
I see progress when 30,000 people use our new feedback tools to tell us what they think of our firearms proposal
I see progress because we have 100 public and stakeholder consultations a year to get proper input on our ideas and drafts
I am satisfied when we defy expectations and have a real debate over existing legislation like we did with the Natura regulations
I am satisfied when we bridge the gap between perception & facts and take political ownership of policies like ecodesign
Our system still favours proposing the new over revising the old, so we must keep working to change attitudes
This is about changing incentives and attitudes, to embed better regulation in the DNA of the @EU_Commission
Yesterday I gave a speech on the importance of better regulation policy in a time of attacks on facts and evidence https://t.co/HhtqUJJOCL

The focus of this Commission is squarely on delivery, but we cannot do it alone. This is a joint responsibility.
We will continue our efforts to improve existing legislation and make it more fit for purpose, more proportionate, better able to deliver.
In the coming year the Commission will put a particular emphasis on implementation and enforcement work across all policy areas.
Europe cannot be the answer to all the problems.But Europe certainly needs to be part of the solution to the biggest & most pressing issues.
The Work Programme is our commitment to Parliament and to European citizens to deliver. We have listened closely to people's concerns.

Press release: Commission proposes mandatory Transparency Register for EU institutions https://t.co/ODWWbdxylJ
We want Parliament and Council to sign up to the same rules. Our proposal would make the Register mandatory for any lobbyists in Brussels.
Transparency has been our priority since day one. We have applied the rule that if you aren't on the Register you don't get a meeting.
Listening to the outside world is not a bad thing. This is a key part of better regulation. We do not have a monopoly on wisdom.
How 'Brussels' makes decisions and who influences them is a matter of public concern.The Commission wants all EU institutions to shed light.
On something like transparency we need to work together and to achieve the highest standards together.
#Transparency The proposals we make today are about rebuilding trust in all EU institutions.
Starting now https://t.co/DAftKBGyFl

RT @EU_Commission: Video: @TimmermansEU explains today's @EU_Commission Opinion concerning the rule of law in Poland
https://t.co/93Ccqq5fNf
My opening remarks from today's press conference on the Rule of Law in Poland: https://t.co/DFidUDYltY
Commission Opinion on the Rule of Law in Poland and the Rule of Law Framework: Questions & Answers https://t.co/SpGMskK0ET
European Commission Press release - Commission adopts Rule of Law Opinion on the situation in Poland https://t.co/Tqjo6RIh6f
Political issues in Poland are the business of politicians in Poland. Our business is preserving the rule of law, in line with the Treaties.
Let me be clear that the Commission does not intend and does not wish to involve itself in a political debate in Poland.
The Polish authorities now have the opportunity to reply and we will continue our dialogue in a structured way based on this exchange.
Our Rule of Law Framework allows the Commission to present its assessment to the Polish authorities in written form.
However, despite our best efforts, until now we have not been able to find solutions to the main issues at stake.
Since January we have been in an intensive dialogue with the Polish government under the Rule of Law Framework.
The EU is built on a common set of values enshrined in the Treaty. These values include respect for the rule of law.

RT @PES_PSE: "Dublin was simply not designed for situations like this one", says @TimmermansEU at the #EPlenary
We will better protect those seeking refuge, thru safeguards for unaccompanied minors & stronger guarantees for families to be kept together
The new asylum system will discourage abuses – with clear obligations for applicants and safeguards against “asylum shopping".
The new system will also be much more efficient and fairer, with shorter processes for assigning responsibility and processing applications.
All Member States will be required to contribute and show solidarity. This may also take the form of financial solidarity.
We propose to introduce a corrective mechanism in our Dublin System. Each Member State's share will be based on clear and simple criteria.
Simple truth is that if Member States do not find common approach, not a single one will be able to handle  that responsibility on its own.
In the past year a few Member States came under incredible strain. This results from shortcomings of the Dublin system in its current form.
Cooperation with third countries, protection in the region and resettlement from there to the EU should become the model for the future.
We need better approach to arrivals. Those who don't seek protection should be returned. Those who do, should be processed efficiently.
We must find ways to help people without them risking their lives in dangerous journeys. We need to take them out of the hands of smugglers.
We need to make sure that people who need protection actually receive it. This is our moral duty as well as our legal responsibility.
Until we are able to build peace and prospects in our neighbourhood and beyond, people will continue to look to the EU for refuge.

Grootste drijfveer achter de politiek is angst. Niets is sterker, verleidelijker voor politici dan om die angst te gebruiken #HuisvanEuropa
